speaker: Young Frasier
text: I specifically requested my macaroni & cheese _al dent e_.

speaker: Young Niles
text: I know.  This lunch is a culinary Hindenberg.

speaker: Young Frasier
text: Niles, have you ever considered that our food may be payback for your recent editoral, "Cafeteria Of Shame"?

speaker: Young Niles
text: Well, they can't intimidate me.  They'll never silence my pen.  I could write an expose on their baked goods alone.

speaker: Young Frasier
text: [_knocks bread roll on table before a pun alert:_] Yes, this is the hardest roll since Hamlet!

speaker: Young Niles
text: Good one, Frasier.  May I use it?

speaker: Young Frasier
text: But of course.  _Fade Back to the present day, Niles and Frasier are in Caf e Nervosa, still whittling on about the food._

speaker: Niles
text: These biscotti represent an all-time low.  Chalky aftertaste, inelegant aroma, spongy!

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, and what is a spongy biscotti but an unwelcome trespasser into Madeline territory?

speaker: Niles
text: Have you seen how stale these pistachios are?  It's like swallowing gravel.  It's a wonder I escaped permanent injury.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_sarcastic:_] Yes, your ability to cheat death at every turn never ceases to amaze.

speaker: Niles
text: Someone's in a mood today.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, sorry Niles.  You know sometimes you just find yourself getting restless?

speaker: Niles
text: I'm fearing I'm about to.

speaker: Niles
text: [_to phone:_] Hello.  Yes?  Really?  Bravo!  _Excellent e! Benissimo!_ [_hangs up:_] You'll never guess who that was!

speaker: Frasier
text: The Three Tenors?

speaker: Niles
text: No, it was my antiques scout.  The present I ordered for Maris's birthday has arrived.  I got her the most exquisite antique saddle.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh.  How's it look on you?

speaker: Niles
text: [_looks at Frasier:_] You won't laugh when you see it.  It is bejewelled but not overdone, much like my Maris.  The craftsmanship is breathtaking.  It's been so expertly restored you can barely see the stitching.

speaker: Frasier
text: Again, like Maris!

speaker: Niles
text: Someone _is_ in a mood today. [_receives bill:_] I'll get this.

speaker: Frasier
text: Thank you Niles, it's... perhaps you can run along to the wine club on your own tonight.

speaker: Niles
text: [_surprised:_] What?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, it'll just be the same old faces rehashing the same boring topics.

speaker: Niles
text: You're more upset than I realised.  Let's do something to take your mind off it.  Dinner?  Chamber music?  There's a wonderful lecture series on the histroy of modern lecture series.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm sorry, I don't think so.  You know, I just feel like being on my own tonight.  You don't mind, do you?

speaker: Niles
text: Of course not, I'll just see you at Puchino for lunch tomorrow.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well maybe we ought to play that by ear as well.

speaker: Niles
text: As you wish.

speaker: Frasier
text: You're not upset, are you?

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier, I'd have to have a pretty fragile ego to be upset just because you want to take some time away from me.

speaker: Waiter
text: Do you want to pay?

speaker: Niles
text: Separate checks, please! [_turns away from Frasier_]  _Scene Two - Apartment Later, back at Frasier's apartment, Martin's card friends are waiting.  There's Roz, Frank, Leo, Jimmy & Duke.  Martin's in the kitchen preparing his food.  Frasier watches him whilst Daphne does the dishes._

speaker: Martin
text: Alright.  Here we go: cold cuts, pizza rolls, deviled eggs, pork roll-ups; all right.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_sarcastic:_] Yes, the ideal buffet for a group of heavyset men over sixty!  I assume everyone's ready to order.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, we're about ready to start our poker game.

speaker: Daphne
text: Don't worry Mr. Crane, I'll be on my way in a minute.

speaker: Martin
text: OK.  Well, we're about ready to start our poker game.

speaker: Frasier
text: I heard you, dad.  I'm just trying to figure out what I'm going to do with myself this evening.  My old routine doesn't seem to satisfy me anymore, I'm trying to think of something new.  Oh, I know - maybe I could join you and the guys for some cards, eh?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, I don't know about that, Frasier; I just don't think you'd fit in!

speaker: Frasier
text: Why not?  Roz is playing!

speaker: Martin
text: Roz is like one of the guys.  She knows more dirty jokes than Duke!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, if that's the criteria, I'm sure I could tell you a tale or two which would make you blush like a school girl.

speaker: Martin
text: That's what I'm afraid of!

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh let him play, it can't hurt anything.

speaker: Martin
text: Alright, come on.  _Martin enters the room with Frasier following carrying the tray. Frasier sits between Roz and Martin._

speaker: Martin
text: Guys, Frasier's going to sit in with us tonight.

speaker: Roz
text: Really?  You're going to play with us.

speaker: Frasier
text: Why not, Roz?  Don't look so surprised.  'Sides, there's nothing I enjoy more than a good old-fashioned night with the guys.

speaker: Frank
text: OK, get ready, seven buck limit high and low, chips to win, high and low, the wheel is no good.

speaker: Frasier
text: Perfect.

speaker: Leo
text: No Check in rays?  Three buck limit.

speaker: Frasier
text: Sounds good.

speaker: Roz
text: You're lost, aren't you?

speaker: Frasier
text: Like a Bedouin in a sandstorm!

speaker: Leo
text: So, you guys got your all-weather tires on ya?

speaker: Frank
text: I'm going to Richie's for some bodywork afterwards.

speaker: Roz
text: Go to Tim's, you get free a overhaul.

speaker: Duke
text: You ever been to Hank's?  Now there's a garage.

speaker: Martin
text: King bets, fifty cents.  Yeah, I've been to Hank's, right next to Mike's Hardware, right?

speaker: Jimmy
text: Why I was in Mike's the other day, they got those new cordless drills.

speaker: Frank
text: Still go to Mike's?  You ought to try Tommy's. They give away free battery testers with every purchase.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm out!  _Frasier gets away from the non-sensical mayhem to Daphne in the kitchen._

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, that was a bust!

speaker: Daphne
text: Be glad before the debate begins over who would be the most fun on a desert island - Angie Dickinson or Ursula Andress?

speaker: Frasier
text: That's ludicrous... it's Angie Dickinson.

speaker: Daphne
text: You know, Dr. Crane, I know it's none of my business but... Oh, never mind.

speaker: Frasier
text: No, no, go ahead.

speaker: Daphne
text: Perhaps you've been feeling restless lately because of a lack of, well, you know, female companionship.  So I thought...

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, dear!

speaker: Daphne
text: Just listen.  I'm meeting my friend Clare for drinks tonight - she's complained of feeling restless...

speaker: Frasier
text: Just stop right there.  I think by now you'd know my policy on fix-up's.

speaker: Daphne
text: She's pretty, she's lonely and she's an underwear model.

speaker: Frasier
text: So you do know my policy.  Off we go!   **SO AUTHENTIC THERE ISN'T AN ICE CUBE IN THE JOINT** _Scene Three - The Fox & Whistle A few moments later, they arrive at "The Fox & Whistle", a typical English pub.  There are English flags around the place and other Anglican items. _

speaker: Daphne
text: Say hello to the "Fox & Whistle."

speaker: Frasier
text: You point her out and I will! [_laughs_]

speaker: Winston
text: [_in English accent from behind the bar:_] Hi-ay love, give us a kiss!

speaker: Frasier
text: Hope he's talking to you.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_goes forward_] Evening, all!

speaker: Clare
text: [_comes over_] Daphne!

speaker: Daphne
text: There's Clare now.

speaker: Frasier
text: My, she's everything you said she was...

speaker: Clare
text: [_excited:_] I'm engaged!

speaker: Frasier
text: And more!

speaker: Daphne
text: When did this happen?

speaker: Clare
text: Well, my old boyfriend, Bob, surprised me two nights ago. You gotta meet him, he's right over there.  _Someone who looks utterly different gives a wave.  He's sitting next to another man._

speaker: Clare
text: He even brought someone you might be interested in.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, he is nice looking, isn't he? _Bob, who is apparently deaf and dumb, slowly mouths, "I LOVE YOU" to Clare while signing the same with his hands._

speaker: Clare
text: Coming, pookie.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh sorry, Dr. Crane, it seems like I've brought you down here for nothing.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh hardly.  If not for you I would have missed seeing the World's Most Nauseating Couple defend their title.

speaker: Daphne
text: We can leave if you like.

speaker: Frasier
text: No, no, you go talk with your friend; I'll have a drink.

speaker: Daphne
text: You sure?

speaker: Frasier
text: Sure. [_turns to bar as Daphne exits_]

speaker: Winston
text: What d'ya need?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, funny, I've been asking myself that same question all day, it seems that lately my life...

speaker: Winston
text: I'll come back. [_serves someone else_] _Scene Four - Apartment Meanwhile, Martin, Roz and the gang are still enjoying their chat over their game of cards._

speaker: Frank
text: I forgot that story!

speaker: Martin
text: Oh geez, it still doesn't top the time Leo and I were sent to break up that fight in the strip joint.

speaker: Leo
text: Oh, boy!

speaker: Martin
text: We walked in there and I'm telling you there was this one girl...

speaker: Frank
text: Hey Marty, Marty!  Maybe you shouldn't tell that story.

speaker: Martin
text: What, because of Roz?

speaker: Roz
text: Oh please, Frank!  If I can handle the Angie/Ursula debate, I think I can handle this!

speaker: Leo
text: But you agree with me on that one, right?  You said you'd rather sleep with Angie?

speaker: Roz
text: One more time Leo. [_slowly:_] If I had to choose, yes!

speaker: Martin
text: Hey Leo, you start telling them that strip joint story; you guy's are going to bust a gut!  Anyone else need a beer? **All Bar**

speaker: Roz
text: Yes!

speaker: Martin
text: Roz?

speaker: Roz
text: Remember?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh geez, I'm sorry, I forgot, yeah! [_goes to the kitchen_]

speaker: Frank
text: What's the matter, Roz?  You think you won't be able to control yourself with all these handsome guys here? [_laughs_]

speaker: Roz
text: It's a little late for that, Frank.  I'm pregnant.

speaker: Frank
text: What?!  That's great!  I remember when my Annie was pregnant. There is nothing more beautiful than a pregnant broad!

speaker: Leo
text: You're in for a real treat, Roz.  The best thing I ever did was having kids.

speaker: Duke
text: You know from the moment you hold that brand new baby in your arms, your whole life changes.

speaker: Jimmy
text: You're right about that!

speaker: Frank
text: What about when they grab your fingers with those little hands, that's one of the greatest feelings there ever is.

speaker: Duke
text: Yeah the joy of seeing them look up at you and smile.

speaker: Jimmy
text: Cherish every moment, Roz.

speaker: Frank
text: He's right.  One minute they're sitting on your lap; you're their whole world.  Next thing: they're growing up, out of the door with lives of their own!

speaker: Leo
text: And it's just you, old and alone in an empty house.

speaker: Duke
text: It's so empty.  _They all sit in morbid silence, thinking about how bad their lives are and how bad Roz's life will be.  Martin enters and is surprised by this lifeless scene._

speaker: Martin
text: Leo, I don't think you told that story right! _Scene Five - the Pub Meanwhile, in the Ladies room at the "Fox & Whistle", Clare and Daphne are having a little chat.  Daphne is carefully brushing out her hair._

speaker: Clare
text: I think that Steven likes you!

speaker: Daphne
text: I hope so.  He's adorable.  I must say I was flattered when he assumed I was an underwear model too.

speaker: Clare
text: I noticed you didn't rush to correct him.

speaker: Daphne
text: There'll be time for that after the wedding! [_they laugh_] Ah, maybe I should just tell Dr. Crane to run along home.

speaker: Clare
text: I'm surprised you even brought your boss down here, I couldn't never relax around mine.  What if he took a liking to the place?

speaker: Daphne
text: [_laughs_] Oh that's nothing I have to worry about, this pub really isn't his style!  _Daphne and Clare leave the ladies to find a big group around the piano singing "Roll Out The Barrel."  Frasier is mid-centre._

speaker: Gang
text: Zing, boom, tararrel! Ring out a song of good cheer! It's time to roll out the barrel! Coz the gangs all here!

speaker: Frasier
text: Daphne, come and sing a song with us!

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, actually...

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, you're not shy about singing in the house.

speaker: Steven
text: You two live together?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes!  She's my dad's health care worker.

speaker: Steven
text: [_to Daphne:_] I thought you modeled underwear!

speaker: Frasier
text: No!  Only if her robes aren't stitched up tight enough! [_laughs_]

speaker: Terrence
text: Come on Frasier, we're going to do "Knees Up Mother Brown".

speaker: Frasier
text: I don't know "Knees Up Mother Brown".  I know what, let's bring some sheet music tomorrow night.

speaker: Daphne
text: Tomorrow?!

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes.

speaker: Daphne
text: But you can't!  I mean... do you know you have that gallery opening tomorrow?

speaker: Frasier
text: No, but if you hum a few bars I'll try to pick it up! [_laughs_]  _The gang begin singing "Roll Out The Barrel" again as Daphne looks bewildered and angry. The scene freezes at the end of the act with Frasier having fun.  This looks similar to the "Cheers" opening credits.  End Of Act One. (Time: 9:12)  Act Two.  Scene One - Apartment Martin is on the phone to Sherry, he's ready for some action._

speaker: Martin
text: [_into phone:_] Hey Sherry, Daphne's finally clearing out for the night.  Why don't you come over?  I'll, er, you know, get a fire going, open a bottle of bubbly, put a little Bobby Darin on the stereo, and then look out, Mackie's back in town! Yes, I thought it up before I called you.  What's the difference?  OK, see you soon. [_Daphne enters_] Wow, Daphne, don't you look beautiful.

speaker: Daphne
text: Thank you.  It's so nice to finally have my pub back again.  At least for a night.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah.

speaker: Daphne
text: You are sure Dr. Crane has plans?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, yeah, Niles called; they're going to the opera.

speaker: Daphne
text: Let's hope it's one of those long German ones - I don't want him showing up for last call!

speaker: Martin
text: Right!

speaker: Frasier
text: Good evening, Daphne.  Wow, you look smashing!

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh thanks, I'm was just on my way out.

speaker: Frasier
text: What, to the "Fox & Whistle"?  I'll go with you!  Let me just grab me mack and me brolly and Bob's your uncle!

speaker: Daphne
text: But wait!  I thought you were going to the opera with your brother?

speaker: Frasier
text: That's tomorrow night.  Gee, I hope Winston's at the pub - I owe him five quid from the other night!

speaker: Daphne
text: Suddenly I'm not feeling so well.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, really?  I hope it's not that flu that's going around.

speaker: Daphne
text: I think I'll just stay home tonight.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, yes, that's probably for the best.  You've got to be careful what you bring down to the pub with you.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_trying to drop a hint:_] Tell me about it!

speaker: Frasier
text: Hello, Niles.

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier.

speaker: Frasier
text: Something the matter?

speaker: Niles
text: [_pouring a sherry_] Oh, I had a rough night last night.

speaker: Frasier
text: How so?

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, I gave Maris her birthday saddle. She was so thrilled she treated me to a little Lady Godiva impression.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, my!

speaker: Niles
text: Apparently the oils in the saddle reacted badly with her cellulite cream and created a powerful epoxy.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, dear!

speaker: Niles
text: Yes, it took an hour and a full bottle of nail polish remover to get her free.  Today her poor little thighs were so sore the only way she could find comfort was to straddle a frozen butterball turkey.  The only thing that cheered me up all day was the thought of our box at the opera tonight.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, that's tomorrow night, Niles.

speaker: Niles
text: No, no, it's tonight.  I have the tickets right here. [_waves them_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, no.

speaker: Niles
text: [_surprised:_] Is there a problem?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well yes, there's a billiard tournament at the pub tonight.

speaker: Niles
text: You're passing up "Orpheus & Eurydice" to shoot pool at some sticky-bear salon?!

speaker: Frasier
text: Yeah well, my partner, Terrence has agreed to skip a family wedding just to participate - I can't leave him in the lurch. Isn't there somebody else who could take my place?

speaker: Niles
text: At this point I just so need to be by myself.  My brother has abandoned me, my wife is cursing my name.  Tonight when Orpheus descends into hell, I'll be there waiting for him with a fruit basket! [_exits, Frasier follows_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Niles!  You can't stay mad at me, I promise I'll make it up to you.  Press for the lift, won't you?  Don't look at me that way, that's what they call it! _Frasier and Niles leave as Martin enters.  He dims the lights down and lights a couple of candles as he prances around, excited.  Daphne suddenly walks in, in robe, and brings the lights back up._

speaker: Daphne
text: Why is it so bloody dark in here?  It's bad enough I have to stay home all evening, I'm not going blind as well!

speaker: Martin
text: What?  You're staying in tonight?

speaker: Daphne
text: I don't have much choice, since that son of yours decided to go to my pub again.  I mean, imagine being so dense that he can completely ruin someone else's evening and not even be aware of it.  This wax is dripping! [_blows out candles_]

speaker: Martin
text: Have you tried maybe dropping a hint? [_pops open the champagne loudly_]

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh believe me, I've dropped plenty; they go right over his head! [_notices bubbly:_] Oh, I'll have a glass of that!

speaker: Martin
text: Daphne, I've got to level with you: Sherry's coming over and I really hoped to have the place to myself tonight.  You know, I really think you should talk to Frasier, and I'm not just saying this because I want you to get the hell out of here! It's your pub and you ought to tell him that he's got to find his own place.

speaker: Daphne
text: I can't say that!

speaker: Martin
text: Well the longer you let it go, the more attached he's going to get to that place.

speaker: Daphne
text: But he's my boss.

speaker: Martin
text: But it's your pub.

speaker: Daphne
text: OK.  That's it, I'm going to talk to him.

speaker: Martin
text: Good for you.

speaker: Martin
text: [_to phone:_] Hello?  No, Maris, sorry, you just missed him. Why are you teeth chattering?  You're kidding me.  Can't you just use the defroster?! _Scene Two - The Pub In "The Fox & Whistle", Frasier is giving his sorrows to Terrence about his billiard playing._

speaker: Frasier
text: Gee Terrence, I never dreamed we'd be eliminated from the tournament in the first round.  Guess I'm a little rustier than I thought.  Hey, maybe you can still make that wedding reception.

speaker: Terrence
text: It's in Liverpool!

speaker: Frasier
text: Well then, [_takes pints_] these are on me.  _Winston notices Daphne and everyone says "hi."  This is getting to be quite the clich e by now._

speaker: Daphne
text: Dr. Crane, I have to talk to you.

speaker: Frasier
text: By all means, Daphne.  Oh, Winston, let's have one of these pints for Miss Moon, please. [_he hands one over_] Oh, this is a really nice surprise, Daphne, you must be feeling better. Here we are.  You make a toast.

speaker: Daphne
text: I don't want you coming down here ever again!

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I guess "here's mud in your eye" sounded mean the first time too!

speaker: Daphne
text: I'm sorry if that sounds a bit harsh, but I don't know what else to do.  This pub is where I come to get away from things - including my job - and you are my boss...

speaker: Frasier
text: Daphne, I'm so sorry.

speaker: Daphne
text: I know that must sound selfish.

speaker: Frasier
text: No, no, not at all.  You know, back in Boston I had a bar like this one, I certainly understand what it's like to have a place where you can get away.  So, we've just got one solution: This is your bar, I'll just go.

speaker: Daphne
text: I do appreciate this, Dr. Crane.  I know you've made friends here too.

speaker: Frasier
text: I've only been coming here a week - you've got a history here!

speaker: Daphne
text: They've become like family to me.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, I'll just settle up and go.

speaker: Freddy
text: Hey, I haven't been gone that long - two months is all.  [_to Daphne:_] Who's this pretty new girl?

speaker: Winston
text: Oh, that's Daphne.  She's Clare's friend.  She's only been coming in the last month or so.

speaker: Frasier
text: A month?

speaker: Daphne
text: [_ignoring:_] Hello.  Well, I'll see you at home, Dr. Crane.

speaker: Frasier
text: You've only been coming down here for a month?

speaker: Daphne
text: That's still longer than you!

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, well there's certainly no way I'm leaving now!

speaker: Daphne
text: What?

speaker: Frasier
text: Daphne, this bar has filled up a void in my life.  I'm not just going to throw that away just because you beat me here by a fortnight!

speaker: Daphne
text: Stop talking like us!

speaker: Winston
text: Here, here, I don't know what you two are arguing about, but we settle things around here with a quick game of cricket. [_gives Frasier some darts_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Darts?

speaker: Winston
text: Yeah, rules are on the board.

speaker: Daphne
text: There's gotta be a better way than that.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh I don't know.  It's decisive, better than standing around here bickering.

speaker: Daphne
text: It's not exactly my game.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, it's not mine either.

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, alright.  Let's try it.

speaker: Frasier
text: You shoot first, Daphne.  You know, I'm rather proud of us: two people in conflict, we've found a civilised way to settle it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, my!

speaker: Daphne
text: Is that good?

speaker: Frasier
text: Quite good.

speaker: Daphne
text: Lucky shot, then.

speaker: Frasier
text: Daphne, If I didn't know better, I'd think you were trying to hustle me!

speaker: Daphne
text: [_laughs_] Oh, not at all.  I may have played a game or two of feathers in my day.

speaker: Frasier
text: A game or two?  You've just made about the most difficult shot on the board!

speaker: Daphne
text: Actually, that's only the second most difficult.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_taken aback_] That's the most difficult.

speaker: Frasier
text: Come to think of it, there might have been a dart board in that bar in Boston... _Scene Three Later, Daphne and Frasier are nearing the end of their game._

speaker: Daphne
text: Well look at that, it's all tied up!

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, who would have guessed those hands are so skilled. Certainly no one who's sampled your corned beef hash! [_throws shot:_] Ha!  I score again!

speaker: Daphne
text: That's not something we hear out of your mouth very often!

speaker: Frasier
text: You don't want to rush this. [_Daphne loses her concentration_] A lot riding on this shot. [_She loses it again_]

speaker: Daphne
text: There is such a thing as sportsmanship.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, really?  This from a woman who made armpit noises during my last round!

speaker: Daphne
text: Sod!

speaker: Frasier
text: [_sarcastic:_] I am so sorry, Daphne!  Now all I have to do is make this relatively simple shot - unless of course you'd like to concede defeat.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_laughs_] That's typical American arrogance.  We Brits don't know the meaning of the word "defeat!"

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh really, then I suppose you're not acquainted with that little spat we refer to as the Revolutionary War!

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, just like a Yank!  Insulting us Brits to cover up your inferiority complex!

speaker: Frasier
text: What exactly should we feel inferior about, your pioneering work in the field of soccer hooliganism?!

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, say your worst.  We both know there isn't as much dignity in this entire country as our Queen's got in her little finger.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_sarcastic:_] Oh yes, you've really bested me there, what could be more dignified than a dainty old sandbag who wears a flowerpot on her head! [_takes shot_] I win!  The bar is mine!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, lose the long faces, lads, I'm staying.  Oh good Lord, I hope you didn't take those little barbs about the motherland seriously!

speaker: Terrence
text: Perhaps you'd better leave now.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Daphne'll tell you there's no greater Anglophile than I. I have all my suits made at Savile Row.  I spell "colour" with a "u!" _But he's gone.  Daphne smiles and takes a stool.  Scene Four The next day, in Caf e Nervosa, Frasier meets Niles after a long time away._

speaker: Frasier
text: Hello, Niles.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, look who's here.  Take a wrong turn on the way to the pub?

speaker: Frasier
text: Actually, that scene has grown tiresome, and I... I miss this place.

speaker: Niles
text: I've spoken to Daphne.  I take it it's over over there.

speaker: Frasier
text: You don't have to rub it in.  Anyway, I know I owe you an apology for the other night so, here.  I've brought you a peace offering. [_hands a CD to Niles_]

speaker: Niles
text: "Orpheus & Eurydice", thank you Frasier. [_gasps:_] The Glyndeborne production!  I don't have this one.

speaker: Frasier
text: You're going to love it!  The choice is particularly moving, and Janet Baker's Act Three aria is...  _Now we travel back in time to prep school where a young Frasier is also giving a peace offering to young Niles._

speaker: Young Frasier
text: -is quite simply it's the best consecutive aria I've ever heard.

speaker: Young Niles
text: Oh thank you, Frasier.  I don't have "Orpheus & Eurydice" on 8-track yet!  I'm surprised to see you - [_sarcastic:_] No woodworking club today?

speaker: Young Frasier
text: Oh, to tell you the truth, I've grown tired of that crowd, with their stupid bookends and birdhouses.  As soon as I've finished slacking my shoe trees I'm out of there.

speaker: Young Niles
text: You got thrown out, didn't you?

speaker: Young Frasier
text: I did not.

speaker: Young Niles
text: Frasier, I can see right through you.

speaker: Young Frasier
text: Are you a psychiatrist?!

speaker: Young Niles
text: Oh no, I'm not a psychiatrist but I can see it in your face...
